The Great Gatsby: Novel Book by F. Scott Fitzgerald
The novel “The Great Gatsby” by author F. Scott Fitzgerald depicts a love story between two people named Jay Gatsby and Daisy Buchanan. This romantic story is a symbol of the decadent culture of the 1920’s in America, depicted by Fitzgerald, who was a direct observer of that unique atmosphere. It is a symbolic and significant story about the American dream and the society that is living in that dream.
The story is told in the third-person narrative, which shows a great number of characters from different walks of life who are in a constant struggle to reach the top and achieve the American dream that is depicted in all its glory. It is a long and enduring search for love, money and a place under the sun. All the characters in the novel are described with their strengths and weaknesses; there are no good or bad characters, just people who make mistakes, live ordinary lives sometimes and take on a “good” or even “fantastic” image; they are not heroes but just ordinary people who make wrong or right turns, but never get ahead.
The novel was published in 1925 and the society described in the novel is still a vivid memory in the contemporary world; it’s the time of enormous change – people live “free” and try to express their individuality in all its forms. That is why Gatsby’s personality that is so different from the majority of people from the same society is so appealing to readers. His wealth, social networks, parties and his unconditional love for Daisy made him a celebrity and a great dealer, but it is a big lie that masks his true self. He is a poor boy from Ohio who is crazy about Daisy Buchanan, who lives far from him and represents the wealth and luxury of the 1920’s life and culture.
In the novel, Gatsby is not actually a hero; he is a person who is so idealistic and pure that he cannot actually reach the top of society and the world’s success. On the other hand, the rich people living in the society Gatsby is part of and the social networks to which he is connected, are so vile and cruel that they cannot tolerate and accept his love for Daisy: they envy him, cannot understand him and don’t believe that he is serious about her. The people who surround him are not aware of Gatsby’s love for Daisy; they don’t want him to be happy in love.
The author uses the symbol and color red in order to show, that the society Gatsby is part of is based on lies and deceits. Nick, a narrator of his own story, claims that the red-colored room is actually filled with “crimson light”. The society is full of lies and cruel people who are constantly pretending to be something they are not (Gordon S. 1984; Fitzgerald. 1978). All the events that take place in the novel, are a part of the endless struggle between Gatsby and Daisy and, on one hand, between Gatsby and the society in which he wants to be accepted and on the other – between Gatsby and the wealth and affluence of the 1920’s American society.
Gatsby is a hero of his own story, and is the only hero in the entire 1920’s society, which is shown as a place where each and every person is not sure if his or her own actions or ideas will stand in the society and be valued and accepted by other people.
The novel by F. Scott Fitzgerald is full of metaphors, symbols and images that can not be forgotten after reading the novel. The most important ones, as well as the recurrent images in the novel, are a green light that Gatsby expects every night and the eyes of Dr. Eckleburg:
Symbols-Green Light
In the novel, “The Great Gatsby” by F. Scott Fitzgerald, the author uses the symbol of green light as an image for Gatsby’s unrequited love for Daisy. The novel depicts a rich and decadent culture in the 1920’s America, and each character is a part of its own struggle to reach the top; however, for the two main characters in the story Gatsby and Daisy, the symbol of the green light is an image of their endless search for a love between them. The symbol is first explained on the first page of the novel, in Chapter 1, when Nick, a narrator of the novel, describes his feelings that are connected with the green light on the end of Daisy’s dock. He explains himself by saying that “[the green light is] the orgastic future that year by year recedes before us” (Fitzgerald 3).
The orgastic future is the image for the American dream, which is described by Fitzgerald as a place where the person lives his or her own fantastic life. The future, which seems so far and unthinkable at the moment when the novel is set (January), gradually fades as the years pass, and there is no chance to actually reach it; as a consequence, even if the person does get everything he or she wants, it doesn’t make that person satisfied and happy.
Later in the chapter, when Nick and Gatsby’s friend Jordan are on their way to meet Gatsby at his mansion, they see his face reflected in the green light on the end of Daisy’s dock: “As we crossed the drawbridge a car came over the rise and Gatsby waved his cap, and I saw that it was a girl he was going to meet, and felt an indistinct alarm. It was Jordan Baker” (Fitzgerald 9).
This event, as well as the entire meeting and conversation of Nick, Gatsby and Jordan, symbolise Gatsby’s unrequited love for Daisy. Jordan is Daisy’s friend and, in the 1920’s where the novel is set, Jordan is actually a person to look up to and admire because she is known to be open-minded and brave. Jordan is in a way a heroine of the novel and is connected to Gatsby because she is a friend of his; she accepts and admires his goals and dreams, and has even “asked him to meet Jordan Baker” (10). In Gatsby’s opinion, Jordan is a great person, but Nick thinks that she is not a good choice because she can never be satisfied with anything that she has and she is full of false rumors. Gatsby “doesn’t believe that Jordan Baker is really good or bad, … she touches the whole of the outer world, from Paris to East Egg and back to West Egg and along the curving shore” (13). She is a symbol of modernity and a person who can actually understand Gatsby’s personality when no other person in the novel can.
It is known that Daisy is Gatsby’s childhood sweetheart and that he has been looking for her all through his miserable adolescence. Daisy was born in a wealthy family, and she lives a privileged life in the 1920’s where the novel takes place. This is a factor of her being separated from Gatsby, whom she has never actually met since their last meeting with each other at least five years ago. Their love for one another is shown in the green light, which is a symbol of hope and illusion for both of them. Each character in the novel, not only Nick as the narrator or Gatsby and Daisy themselves, have their own understanding of both the green light and the world they are living in: they all feel that there is no hope in their lives, and this green light is actually for them.
Daisy is the object of the endless search for Gatsby and what he has been looking for all his life. This fact is actually stated by Nick’s character who claims that everyone, even though they pretend not to be interested, knows that “all of us must at least half believe that Daisy is incurable and all of us are enjoying it” (Fitzgerald 73).
Every event in the novel that shows Gatsby’s love for Daisy, is accompanied by the presence of a green light. As Nick, Daisy and Tom begin to drive towards the bridge, it becomes clear that Gatsby’s dream of a happy life with Daisy will not come true. In the scene, Gatsby “had forgotten to kiss Daisy when they were saying goodbye and she had given him his cuff button back and known that it was all up with them from the first moment” (Fitzgerald
77). Gatsby knows that the only thing he has right now is the hope for Daisy, and this hope for him is in the green light.
Later on, Gatsby “went over to West Egg, snaked along the roadway. and stopped reluctantly at her house” (Fitzgerald 89). Nick and Jordan both feel that Gatsby’s presence will actually ruin Daisy’s peace and she will not be able to get rid of him: “’It’s up to [Gatsby]. I’m a rotten liar,’ [Daisy] cried out. [Gatsby] [was] standing right beside her and trying to kiss her and she wasn’t letting him. [Gatsby] couldn’t go away now. [Daisy] didn’t say another word. She began to cry” (Fitzgerald 102). In this scene, Gatsby’s love for her can be seen clearly, as well as the feeling that he cannot actually reach her heart because she is unattainable for him. Gatsby is a real dreamer and he has come to the conclusion that “Daisy was his whole life” (Fitzgerald 117). Daisy, however, is a married woman with a child and there is no way for her to leave her husband and her family; therefore, Gatsby’s endless love for her will probably never lead to fulfillment. Nick also describes this scene by saying that “[Gatsby is] one of those men who … know nothing of discipline” (Fitzgerald 124).
When Nick leaves West Egg and arrives in East Egg to see Tom and Daisy, he describes the green light on the last page of the chapter:
“Gatsby believed in the green light, the orgastic future that year by year recedes before us. It eluded us then, but that was no matter—to-morrow we will run faster, stretch out our arms further… And one fine morning— – – –“It was after we’d started with him and I was almost wishing I was back where I started from, when I remembered Gatsby’s Cafe, so we drove by there. It was on the corner, at the beginning of the white blocks, and as we came opposite [it] the door opened and a single pale gold eye looked into [our] coach” (Fitzgerald 131).
Gatsby’s desire to reach Daisy is shown through his endless waiting for the green light on the horizon that is visible from his mansion. From the very beginning of the novel, he has been waiting; therefore, it can be concluded that he has spent all his life waiting for that special moment. Nick’s character describes the green light as the endless pursuit of people of the society in which Gatsby lives and his own. As soon as people see that Gatsby has something that no one else will have, they start to reach out for it. For Gatsby, as described by Nick, the endless search for Daisy ends on the last page of the novel when he gets hit by the car and there is nothing left to wait for and nothing more to strive for. In the end, the green light can also represent Daisy’s final thoughts about her husband Tom where her love and her feelings in general are very inaccurate and confusing. The green light could also be Daisy’s final hope for Gatsby and his endless pursuit for her. It could also be that Daisy never really believed in him to begin with; she is a person who is very materialistic and she doesn’t love Gatsby, she is just in love with him.
The eyes – Dr. T. J. Eckleburg
The green light and Dr. Eckleburg’s eyes depict two events that took place in the 1920’s. They also are the endless symbols of Gatsby’s love for Daisy and his inability to reach her. As mentioned previously, the green light is actually Gatsby’s unconditional love for Daisy and his own illusion; it is the light of hope and dream. Dr. Eckleburg’s eyes are just like the green light; they are the symbols for people’s illusion and the constant desire to reach their dream that is inevitable and will never happen. Dr. Eckleburg could also represent death, which is another unforgettable image of the 1920’s in America.
For Daisy, death is represented by the green light: whenever it disappears, it is almost like it is a person who has died. There is a scene when Tom, Daisy’s husband, gets angry because Gatsby is “killing himself for a girl he [doesn’t] [even] know”(Fitzgerald 124). He says that he was under the impression that he was fighting for Daisy’s love instead of Daisy fighting for her own happiness and life. Essay about Harper Lee's To Kill a Mockingbird
Harper Lee's 'To Kill a Mockingbird' is a novel published in 1960 set in the American South in the 1930's. The novel was influenced by Lee's own childhood, in particular the events that surround the trial of black man Tom Robinsons, who is accused of raping a white woman, Mayella Ewell. Although the novel is based during the thirties, the story itself appears at times to be a 'slice of life' novel, which describes the everyday happenings of the protagonist, a small girl called Scout.…
In Harper Lee’s To Kill a Mockingbird, the reader is introduced to Scout and Jem Finch, siblings of two and that live in Maycomb County, Alabama at the beginning of the novel. Throughout the novel, Scout and Jem learn valuable lessons from the experiences they go through. The reader also gets a sense of the racial discrimination that existed in the town. While it is a fictional story, the fact remains, this was a time where racial unrest existed in the United States, and this story…
To Kill A Mocking Bird Essay
In the 1930s in Maycomb County, prejudice against people colored is at an all-time high. Harper Lee’s novel, To Kill A Mocking Bird, focuses on a lawyer named Atticus Finch, who takes it upon himself to try a case for a black man named Tom Robinson. Atticus is a lawyer that truly believes in his client and knows that they will win their case. In addition, he must defend Tom because of his friendship with the Robinsons and their family. While this case is taking place Atticus’ two…
To Kill A Mocking Bird Comparison
This essay will be looking at two novels by two different authors that have the similarities and themes to the novel To Kill A Mocking Bird by Harper Lee to be analyzed. The novel that I have chosen to compare are the books "Of Mice and Men" by John Steinbeck and "Slaughterhouse-Five" by Kurt Vonnegut. They both share similar themes of racism and prejudice, loneliness and alienation. Both were written in the twentieth century and both novels were banned for their explicit sexual references…
Essay Harper Lee's To Kill a Mockingbird
In the novel, To Kill a Mockingbird by Harper Lee, a white woman accuses a black man of assaulting her and rape, while her father hires a black man to defend the accused man. Atticus Finch has to defend the man in the court. In both the court room and in the home, there are many racial incidents. In the court room, there is only one black person, a maid named Calpurnia, who talks to her boss on how to save a black man from the white society. Also, the jury is all white men and none of the…

instruction: In the painting “The Persistence of Memory” by Salvador Dali, what is the significance of the melting clocks? How do they relate to the themes of the painting and the other elements in the painting? Please provide evidence from the painting to support your answer.
prompt: r longInter Line Variable margin HE
combined_input: In the painting “The Persistence of Memory” by Salvador Dali, what is the significance of the melting clocks? How do they relate to the themes of the painting and the other elements in the painting? Please provide evidence from the painting to support your answer. r longInter Line Variable margin HE
generated_output:
E EHF I.
Dali depicts a landscape scene of his native, Spanish countryside. He is most well known for his abstract surrealist style and his work is not representative in any respect due to his artistic ability and innovativeness. He was born in 1904 and grew up in Madrid and was very talented. He studied at the Royal Academy and at the age of 18 was awarded first class for a painting he did. It was not long before he met a young poet and friend, Federico Garcia Lorca and soon they were travelling the country together, making artworks and exploring themes and ideas. This was a time when Spain was under the rule of Franco, who was known for being heavily against the arts, this may have been a time of stress and depression for Dali, so he would have liked to have escaped the country at this tough and trying time.
The painting itself shows various surreal symbolism. In this painting the artist has created a landscape scene, full of various features with a central focal point. This focal point could be the melting clock that has been created as it is the only detail that cannot be linked to the scene but is something central and something that the viewer is drawn to immediately. Dali’s landscape is very abstract as he did not aim to capture reality in anyway. From a distance the viewer may see a simple landscape but they would recognise features such as trees but if they look closer they would see that the trees are melting away. Not only does the melting clock symbolise time, because it is ‘melting’, it also symbolises the decay of hope and depression. Another key symbol in the painting is the figures of the people walking through the scene, these people could be seen as being trapped in the scene due to the bars and walls around it.
In this painting it could be deduced that Dali was in distress with regards to his personal life. Spain was not a good place to be at the time due to the political and economical struggles they were having. The melting clock symbolises the loss of time because the future he had hoped for had been taken away. The idea of people being kept captive like animals was an idea that he and Federico Garcia Lorca explored and may be connected with the feeling that they were stuck in Spain when they wanted to be free.
Even though this painting may seem random on the surface, it tells a very detailed story of distress that someone would have felt at the time.
Dali had many personal demons that he needed to work through in order to reach the artistic mindset he needed to create his best work.
